questions.questionText: What is dynamic programming, and how does it differ from recursion and greedy algorithms?
questions.correctAnswer: Dynamic programming (DP) is an optimization technique that solves problems by combining solutions to subproblems, storing these solutions to avoid recomputation. DP differs from recursion by using memoization/tabulation to avoid repetition; greedy algorithms make locally optimal choices without considering subproblems.
questions.explanation: DP applies to problems with overlapping subproblems and optimal substructure, such as the Fibonacci sequence or knapsack problem. DP stores previously computed results to streamline calculation, recursion does not.
